Literature Review:
The intricate relationship between diet and the gut microbiome has been increasingly recognized as a crucial factor in the development and progression of gastrointestinal (GI) disorders. The gut microbiome plays a pivotal role in modulating the host's physiological response to dietary nutrients, and alterations in this interaction have been implicated in various GI diseases, including irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This review aims to summarize the current understanding of the diet-microbiome interaction in GI disorders and discuss strategies to modulate this interaction using microbiome-targeted therapies.

The gut microbiome is composed of trillions of microorganisms that reside in the gastrointestinal tract and play a crucial role in maintaining host health. The gut microbiome is influenced by dietary factors, such as fiber, polyphenols, and short-chain fatty acids, which can either promote or inhibit the growth of specific microbial populations. Recent studies have shown that the concurrent and sequential utilization of dietary nutrients by the host and gut microbiota determines the eventual bioactive metabolite profiles in the gut and the biological effect of these metabolites on GI physiology.

In IBS, the gut microbiome plays a key role in modulating the host's physiological response to dietary nutrients. Studies have shown that individuals with IBS have altered gut microbiota compositions compared to healthy individuals, with a decrease in the abundance of beneficial bacteria such as Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus (1, 2). Furthermore, dietary interventions that promote the growth of these beneficial bacteria have been shown to improve symptoms of IBS (3, 4).

In IBD, the gut microbiome is also implicated in the development and progression of the disease. Studies have shown that individuals with IBD have altered gut microbiota compositions compared to healthy individuals, with an increase in the abundance of pathogenic bacteria such as Escherichia and Clostridioides (5, 6). Furthermore, dietary interventions that reduce the abundance of these pathogenic bacteria have been shown to improve symptoms of IBD (7, 8).

The mechanisms underlying the diet-microbiome interaction in GI disorders are complex and multifaceted. Recent studies have shown that the gut microbiome influences the host's physiological response to dietary nutrients through the production of bioactive metabolites, such as short-chain fatty acids and metabolites of polyphenols (9, 10). These metabolites can either promote or inhibit the growth of specific microbial populations, and alterations in their production have been implicated in various GI diseases.

Several concepts can be gleaned from the findings on the diet-microbiome interaction in GI disorders. Firstly, distinct effects of an individual metabolite can influence diverse GI diseases. For example, short-chain fatty acids have been shown to have anti-inflammatory effects in IBD, while promoting the growth of beneficial bacteria in IBS (11, 12). Secondly, similar dietary interventions can have different effects on multiple disease states. For example, a diet high in fiber has been shown to improve symptoms of IBS, while reducing inflammation in IBD (13, 14). Finally, the need for extensive phenotyping and data collection is highlighted to help make personalized diet recommendations.

In conclusion, the diet-microbiome interaction plays a crucial role in the development and progression of GI disorders. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms underlying this interaction and to develop effective microbiome-targeted therapies. Personalized diet recommendations based on individual gut microbiota compositions and metabolic profiles may provide a promising approach to managing GI diseases.
